title: Will electric cars replace gas cars in twenty years? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the U.S. in twenty years I'd expect electric cars to be somewhere between 20% and 40% of the cars on the road. I'd expect a good proportion of families to own one electric and one ICE vehicle. I'd expect new vehicles to be about half and half. Things that slow complete adoption of electric cars are. Age of our fleet. The median age is 12 years. That means if every car from here onward was electric, 12 years from now our fleet would be half electric and half ICE. We aren't even close to that sales mark.Range. This is improving and in someways this makes it worse. Why would a person buy an electric car now to keep for 6 or 7 years if they are going to be much better in 3 years. When I lived in San Antonio it was over 40 miles to the other side of the city. A car with a 150 mile range is marginal in that situation and I basically end up back at home with a car that's not useable until I recharge it. With an ICE car I can solve the refuel problem in 10 minutes max.Charging infrastructure. A lot of people live in apartments, houses with on street parking, mobile home courts and a bunch of other situations that aren't going to allow them to install a good charger. Until there are a lot of electric cars landlords have no incentive to install charging stations unless they can charge more. I suspect in some cases a lot more. There may come a time when chargers are mandated by code, but that is going to take a lot of political capital to make happen in a lot of places. In fact in many ruralish places there really isn't a structure to mandate it. For a while I had a San Antonio address but lived in an unincorporated part of Bexar county. The city had a little control over building but not much.What I'm going to call the bullshit factor that doesn't necessarily come from the electric car industry but they are certainly a “victim” of it. People know that at least in the past EPA mileage figures weren't what they could count on. CFLs and later LEDs weren't as bright and last no were as long as they said they would and a bunch of similar things. People don't trust the range figures.

I find it hilarious that people can tell the future because their car is electric and they got the money to get one along with installing a charger that can recharge as quickly as 20 minutes. I dont have the ability to charge an EV even at level 1 because the outlets in the garage only will work with power tools and fans. Anything beyond that you trip the circuit breaker and let's face it, you dont want to start an electrical fire by plugging in something that is unsafe. Itll cost me $3,000 or more to upgrade my wiring or I can buy a new gas Honda Civic for under $25k and not worry about the wiring as I wont need to do anything with it. In my opinion even in China and Europe the EV market will stagnate at around 30% of car sales would be EV and the rest would be combustion engine vehicles. Why, because no matter what EVs has limitations. EV owners think they are superior but gas cars drive further, can be refueled to full capacity every time, only use 15% or less additional fuel in the winter, takes 5 minutes to refuel.. ..but the arguments continue which is really better. Supposedly EVs are cheaper to maintain, you charge overnight, you don't drive over 30 miles a day and you'll be stopping every 3 hours sitting for 30 or more minutes to rest anyways on road trips. But the reality is if EVs are so great there would be no need for countries to outright make bans of new combustion engine sales when 99% are still buying new gas vehicles. So no I don't think EVs will replace gas anytime soon.

No, but it’s possible that there will be more of them than gas cars. Electric cars aren’t the end-all in transportation; they’re a third option, next to gas and diesel. They’ll meet the needs of 80–90% of owner requirements, but there’s still that 10–20% it won’t. Commuter cars will skew toward electric. Cars that are heavily driven over long distances will stay gasoline - I know every EV owner likes to rationalize how “great” it is to take a 30–90 minute break from driving a long trip while waiting for charging, but the reality is that’s a trade-off that many users aren’t willing to make (myself included - I wouldn’t use my EV for a long road trip, period). Heavy trucks will still primarily use diesel. Diesel is more energy dense than any battery that exists, and “time is money” in the trucking business - if your wheels aren’t turning, you aren’t getting paid. The Tesla and Nikola semi trucks have too short of a range and take too long to charge to be viable for long hauls. If charge times improve (to, say, the 5–10 minute range) or battery swaps become the standard, this will change and EV’s will likely replace gas vehicles. As for diesel, I predict we’ll still have diesel vehicles on the road 100 years from now.

Eventually, the EV will replace the internal combustion powered vehicle for a few reasons. Foremost will be the appreciable effect on pollution, specifically greenhouse gasses overall and so called “point of source” pollution which refers to the immediate emissions from the vehicle and the net improvement in air quality for the individual, especially in regions where there are a high concentrations of traffic. Another less obvious benefit will be a reduction in noise pollution. Next would be tangible improvements in efficiency, cost and performance which is something that has value to the people purchasing the vehicle. Since EVs are more efficient at converting fuel into power and power into motion the end user enjoys a reduction in driving costs. This is also compounded by the less complex more reliable drivetrains requiring less maintenance and due to the way electric motors generate power and the packaging advantages inherent in small motors with the low placement of batteries over their ICE powered counterparts. Finally there will also be a substantial benefit to EV manufacturers since EVs will have considerable value to the consumer and are cheaper to produce compared to ICE vehicles which will translate into more profit for vehicle manufacturers since consumers comparatively are willing to pay more for an EV product when comparing profit margins on vehicles. For example the typical ICE powered vehicle after all investment is included (design and manufacture) the typical profit margin is between 4 and 7% and can be as low as 1%. On the other hand Tesla maintains they see as much as a 30% margin on their various vehicles which is a very substantial increase over ICE vehicles and that includes a less efficient operation. If Tesla can achieve economies of scale comparable to a traditional vehicle manufacturer that profit margin could increase substantially. When will it happen? Hard to say but I suspect the tipping point will be much like cigarette smoking where it will become largely unacceptable to own and operate an ICE vehicle both due to shifting social attitudes and some government intervention coupled. Along the way people will simply be sold on the inherent advantages of the EV product (which of course is another discussion altogether since vehicle consumers more than any other are so called “bench racers” where perceived performance advantages which largely translate into illegal and reckless driving have merit). Now in the interest of fairness I have to admit I’m one of the knuckle draggers. I love my internal combustion powered vehicles specifically in a rear wheel drive format hooked to a manual transmission. For me the EV is the antithesis of all I hold dear when it comes to driving since I love the interaction with the vehicle but I’m fine with the future since like horses, wagons, sail boats, camping, bolt-action and black powder rifles there will be a place for anachronisms like me. Probably on a road course and a quarter mile track with alcohol for fuel (refineries will eventually give way to solar and wind farms so petroleum will become increasingly rare and expensive and oil will move to other sources for profit but alcohol will always have a place) but there none the less. And while being an admitted luddite I can’t deny the mostly positive effect EVs will have for the future as we approach a planet filled with eleven billion people and to be frank I came along at a good time. Old enough to remember both golden ages of internal combustion engine performance and having the space and freedom to use them mostly without the increasing social stigma as we go through a generational change and social values change. Not a bad trade indeed since by the time ICE vehicles almost solely become the province of the 1% I’ll be mostly too old to drive anyway and besides I’ll either have my autonomous EV people pod or order up transportation from an autonomous ride hailing service by the time that happens anyway.

Will electric cars replace gas cars in twenty years? Yes. Without a doubt or at least certtainly in new car sales. The UK and other European countries have said all new cars will be at least hybrid by 2040. But as battery range in plug-in-hybrids increases, people will see the engine being used less. Then they will be annoyed by the expensive servicing cost for the engine that is only used rarely. Also as engines are used less - liquid fuel is used less, so the fuel filling stations start to close down - so you get range anxiety in an engine car. I heard only last week, that Porsche are going 100% electric in all cars by 2030. Now here’s the thing - I often ride my bicycle in the evening. When the air is clean, you can really smell when a car goes past - and its worse when its a diesel. And yes VW-Audi cars do seem to smell worse. When people get used to breathing clean air, they will start getting pissed at people driving stinky old engines cars down their street.

Not even close. Petroleum is hard coded into the infrastructure of virtually all automotive markets. There will need to be an enormous transformation of our infrastructure to support this move. Think of how many gas stations you see on your drive to work every day? You will need the same number, if not more, of charging stations to support the move to EV. Additionally, companies will start incentivizing ICE cars towards the end to make them very attractive to drive, the nations of OPEC will likely greatly reduce the cost per barrel because without huge markets like the US their primary export will disappear. Supply and Demand principles will be very interesting to see at work during this transition. If you could buy a brand new 2025 Ford F-150 for 20k and fuel was $0.98 per gallon or buy a 100k EV Tesla model Z……which one do you pick? Truly a great time to be alive and witness this first hand.

If we start producing our own electricity cheaply then electric cars will become extremely cheap to run, that seems sensible, please check the price evolution of solar PV prices. Also battery prices are dropping. and they are charging faster new AUDI e-tron can charge at 150KW when facilities available [That is: 300km/185miles in 30min ] Some European countries are completely banning by 2040 ICE cars (petrol+diesel) [note: cars not lorries or busses] Based on this and also a shift in perception in the next 10 years (If you buy a petrol car you’ll be perceived as a selfish unnecessary pollutant), then I’d say YES. Exactly in 20 years ICE cars will be stopped. Maybe a bit before. Ideally Private transport will disappear will become too expensive and unnecessary where you can use some kind of driverless UBER to take you from A to B. Obviously, my own opinion. Here some links to support my opinion.  Battery prices per KW/h of storage $100/kWh Tesla Battery Cells This Year, $100/kWh Tesla Battery Packs In 2020 beating the expectations for two years ago.  France & UK to ban ICE cars by 2040 France to ban sales of petrol and diesel cars by 2040 Britain to ban sale of all diesel and petrol cars and vans from 2040 And people’s perception is shifting. Buying a Diesel Car Today is Selfish and Irresponsible

No but hold on Maybe YES Diesel consumer vehicles will be the first to go, then midsized diesel trucks, it’s happening now in U.K. the contract company for IKEA Wincanton, I saw two full electric trucks at IKEA Thurrock Electric truck - Wikipedia The main instigators are going to be the cities of the UK. Britain's most polluted towns and cities Next big big thrust will come from that German company that’s been prosecuted for telling porkies and fiddling figures about diesels now VW this mea culpa mea maxima culpa company has declared they are going electric their first production BEV is coming in three versions the ID3 they had 10,000 orders in 1day lead time 2020. Other legacy manufacturers will come online by 2022–2025. New Volkswagen ID.3: 15,000 pre-orders for all-electric hatch Consumers will see a vast array of vehicles in the next couple of years. Governments might slap an environmental tax on new petrol/diesel vehicles in the next year or two anything from £1000 to £3,000 per annum All older cars might find when they go in for their MOT they don’t pass the environmental standards. So yes the greater % of vehicles on the road by 2039 will be Zero EMISSIONS vehicles. Well that’s my 2 pennies worth. I drive a Nissan 2017 Leaf 30kWh cost per mile £0.03pennies

They could have long ago if they were stil not like IC cas - great lumps of lead. Possibly a century ago BAKER Electrics etc were common. Now my solar-charged Tricar 25 years ago has already replaced my several years of IC vehicles including 2 VW Kombi, a TR3, a 1927 US$1,500 Rolls Royce Phantom Town Car mint condition, Brit 3 wheel fibreglass 1/4 ton Reliant (70 mph, 70 mpg) the best vehicle ever. Why? My homemade Award-Winning 1WD, 3-wheel, 40 kg ¼ hp electric solar-charged dual Tricar made largely from junk, angle aluminum + plywood is well over 1/4 century & still looks & performs brand new; needing no rego, licence - not had for decades - or insurance on highways, not motorways, Free on trains & ferries. This is over 50 times lighter than the ridiculously heavy electric cars appearing. Dachshund dog or goat helped pull my teen bike up hills. Mini electric folding 3-wheel seated scooter, but with a trailer + small solar panel feeding a small Inverter, which when scooter battery is thus charged gives it a 50km range at 20km/h. Brilliant. Can’t do without my micro geared same weight folding Brompton UK bike that has been round the world with me to Glasgow Conference; & I can strap on a suitcase where it sits on a piece of angle iron + elastic hooks.

They'll never replace gas cars. Because this is America and regardless of what the fake media and snowflakes want you to believe, we'll always love our pickups, huge SUVs, muscle cars, and high performance vehicles. Plus the technology will NEVER be there to replace many functions of utility or performance that combustion engines provide. We're 20 years away from making EVs really even relevant in American society. And the simple fact that overall they're not better for the environment (how do you think electricity is made - coal and fossil fuels. Where are the spent batteries going. The chemicals in the batteries. The cars don't last as long so where are the junkers going. Etc, etc). Technology and the chemicals used to make all of the electronics is far more devastating that natural fossil fuels. The fact most red blooded Americans know “global warming” is a BS lie made up decades ago by the far left and to this day without any scientific proof to take away your rights. So to answer your question in short, EVs will never be anything more than a niche market in America. Because there's still enough men and women with backbone and nuts in this country to counteract you lame ass snowflake liberals

The problem isn’t the cars. It’s the electrical infrastructure. The infrastructure is currently at the breaking point. It’s outdated and will require a tremendous amount of money to upgrade. Where is the money going to come from to bring 200+ AMP charging circuits to every electrical car? Every transformer and every powerline will have to increase in capacity to bring that kind of power to every household. Even now, in California where the adoption rate is high, if you want to do a slow 20 amp charge, most of the charging stations are taken and most of the businesses don’t have the additional power capacity to put charging stations in for their employees. And if we do update the grid, transformers and household power panels, we will need many more power plants to produce the power.

They are replacing them now…. If your question is ‘Will electric vehicle replace ALL gas/diesel cars in the NEXT 20 years?’ I would say no.. My belief is that a good percentage of passenger vehicles will be replaced by ALL electric vehicles and electric/ internal combustion engine (ICE) hybrid cars…. But in the industrial areas such as heavy trucking (semis.) and mid size trucking ( pickup trucks/ delivery vans etc.) that a larger percentage will still be ICE powered vehicles…UNLESS.. there is a radical change in the design of battery power density (where batteries get smaller/lighter for the amount of power they produce) and at the same time a reduction in price per watt/hour of these batteries, with a equivalent / better life expectancy and safety (not going to blow up etc.)….If this happens, and I will not be surprised if it does, then my opinions on the above will change leaning more towards ‘yes’ for heavy and mid size commercial vehicles….

Almost all new cars sold will be electric in 2030, or before. The existing fleet will still be mostly ICE. There will always be a small amount of ICE cars left. You still see a few horses around don’t you ? But for all practical purposes, all new vehicules will be electric. Reasons: Price: everything depends on price. if it’s cheaper people will buy it. Maintenance cost: less maintenance, less moving parts, less hasle. Refueling: You might laugh at this one. But think about it, why do we need gas stations ? Because you can’t produce your own gas or diesel at home. They have become prevalent and convenient because they are everywhere. You never worry about not finding a gas bar. Now, in 10 years, when the fleet is reduced to half its size. What do you think will happen ? Gas stations will become scarce, most will close. People are going into growing businesses, not dying ones. Try running around finding a gas station because you can’t charge at home. Now range anxiety has switched side. Anyways, watch Tony Seba’s videos to understand the big picture.

When you think of electric cars, the resistance in the US has been people not wanting to be caught dead in a Prius. But imagine showing a tough truck owner this - RAM 1500 - 305 Horsepower, Towing capacity 6500 lbs, 0–60 in 6.5 seconds Range of 440 miles on a tank of gas.Rivian Electric Truck (Available next year)- 754 Horsepower, 11,000 lb towing capacity, 0–60 in 3 (!) seconds. Range, 400 miles on a charge Granted, the electric vehicles are new, but Amazon just bought 100,000 Rivians for their delivery fleet. Once people see these specs, and realize how much cheaper the electricity is than gas, I suspect the flip will happen a lot sooner than expected.

Personal opinion: We'd replace gasoline commuter cars in less than 5 years if battery SWAP stations were built instead of charging stations. Just imagine how much quicker than charging your batteries or even than pumping fuel it would be to swap your depleted battery for a freshly charged and tested one. Slide or drop out the dead bank and slide in the fresh bank. Done. I'd write the cheque myself to develop this program if I could. But instead we'll all keep burning fossil fuels while engineers attempt to conquer Ohm’s Law with current technology. I say use the tech we have now to develop swapping stations. Then work on producing longer lasting, faster charging batteries while converting millions of drivers to electric almost overnight. That's the only way I'd personally replace all my internal combustion powered vehicles with electric.

I will begin by using history. When WWII began for the U.S. virtually all railroad locomotives in the country were steam powered. But there were some diesel-electrics mostly used for luxury passenger service. Twenty years later the last of the steam engines in service were being celebrated as they were replaced with the more efficient, easier to service and run Diesel-electric engines. Nostalgia for the age of steam still runs strong, especially amongst my generation, born during the war years, but now the nostalgic railroad enthusiasts include the early diesel-electrics. I think the other commenter here have not considered what the electric car is becoming today. Just a better type of car. There will be efforts to save the more iconic ICE types as collectables, but with the fast improving EV’s and self driving becoming common, the paradigm shift going up at a non-linear rate is nearly upon us.

I think in 5 years, for certain types of cars, close to 100% of new car sales will be EVs, for the simple reason that they will be cheaper than their gas counterparts. And you won’t find anyone willing to pay more for an inferior vehicle. It will probably take another 5 years after that for all type of vehicles up to and including large SUVs to be available in all electric with acceptable range. Now cars last a long time, so you will see SOME gas cars that are bought between 5–10 years from now still on the road 10–15 years later, but 20 years from now I would estimate that fewer than 20–25% of the cars you see on the road (in the US and Europe at least) will be internal combustion. EV sales are growing exponentially, and this will result in a very rapid uptake within the next few years.

They can do just that today and a year or two ago. The only fuel car you have trouble replacing is an offroad work car. The flexibility you need in suspension and body just is not there, and frankly I think because the need is not there. The biggest need is replacing cars in cities and rural areas. Stop kids from developing asthma and breathing issues and noise pollution that is driving everyone insane. For all normal family travel, work and leisure, there are a lot of great full EV cars out there with hugely lower maintenance fees and lower running bills, by far

Car manufacturing companies are now committing to an electric future. However, the rate of success relies on the reliability of the battery. No doubt, present-day electric motors are compact, emission-free, and extremely efficient than ever. But that electric motor needs an accumulator to store and deliver power. As accumulators can store only a small fraction of energy in oldie propellant, so maximum electric vehicle's of present day can go run out of juice in a transient moment. The car companies need to work creatively and dedicatedly if they want electric roadsters to rule the world in near future.

This answer is from an Indian perspective. Personally, I believe this is going to happen in 15 years. Not 25. Users are just not aware of how beneficial it is to use an electric vehicle over a gas guzzler. As the person who uses one, I can certify that the cost of maintenance is less than 10% of that of an internal combustion engine. The number of moving parts are 1/20th compared to that of an internal combustion engine. The only part that really requires thinking over would be the battery. It will give up on you in 5 years. but the amount have saved on petrol or diesel over the five years is more than compensating for the cost of a new battery. Consider this. I spend rupees 65 to fully charge my electric car, which is less than a litre of petrol. My mileage is 120 km. My cost of running is 65 / 120. Which works out to ~ 50ps per km. It is the best solution for in city commuting. Range again is a concern for long distance usage. but I believe business companies will get into the mode of looking for recharge points or battery exchange points to overcome this fallacy. in fact I think there is a big market for battery recharge points or battery exchange points.

Q: Will electric cars replace gas cars in twenty years?A: Short answer is no. Long answer is “hybrids” are “electric cars” and as such burn gas too. It will be interesting to see what the “sales mix” is in 20 years though.
NO.

I would expect electric cars to be at least 95% of new sales if battery production increases as predicted and battery density improves a little. ICE cars will then becomes uneconomic to manufacture so there will be a decreasing range to choose from.

The future is electric cars, because we are facing lot of pollution problems with these petrol, diesel and gas vehicles. All citizens will start purchasing electric cars in coming years, by another 20 years , only solution is electric vehicles, For our next generation survival electric vehicles are only option, please encourage to all to use electric vehilcles
Electric Cars May Rule the World’s Roads by 2040 Electric Cars May Rule the World’s Roads by 2040
